I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
the Kingdom of Thailand for the Greater Mekong Subregion Highway Expansion Phase 2 Project.  
 
2. 
The proposed project will (i) upgrade about 125 kilometers (km) of national highway in the 
northeastern region of Thailand from two-lane highway to four-lane highway; and (ii) strengthen 
capacity in road safety management by introducing road safety audits and road safety awareness 
training for the executing agency during project implementation. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

A. 
 
3. 
As  the  second-largest  economy  in  Southeast  Asia,  Thailand’s  development  potential  is 
strong.  Since  the  late  1980s, Thailand  has  made  remarkable progress  in  social  and  economic 
development, moving from a low-income country to an upper middle-income country (UMIC) in 
2011.  Thailand’s  economy  is  diversified,  and  manufacturing  is  the  main  sector  contributing  to 
economic  growth.  Transport  infrastructure  is  an  important  component  of  the  economy  for  the 
mobility of goods and people to provide access to economic opportunities and social services.   
 
4. 
Transport sector and government sector strategy. Thailand’s transport sector is more 
developed than its immediate Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) neighbors including Cambodia, 
the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR), and Myanmar. Thailand depends heavily on 
road  transport  for  economic  activities.  The  road  transport  subsector  serves  98%  of  passenger 
traffic and 95% of freight traffic in the country. The road network has a total length of 471,010 km, 
comprising 70,660 km of highways, 350 km of controlled-access expressways or motorways, and 
about 400,000 km of local roads.1 More than 98% of the road network is paved to an all-weather 
standard,  and  has  been  extended  nationwide  to  reach  more  than  98.5%  of  the  country’s 
population. The railway network covers 4,043 km, and serves the capital Bangkok and 47 of the 
country’s 76 provinces. More than 90% of the railway network is single-track lines. Railways play 
a small role in passenger and freight traffic. For urban transport, most person trips are made by 
private mode in major cities in Thailand, including Bangkok. Aimed at developing Thailand as a 
regional hub in the GMS, the government’s transport sector development strategy is to improve 
road and rail infrastructure and urban transport. The strategic goal is to strengthen connectivity 
throughout  the  country  by  expanding  the  road  network,  transforming  railway  lines  from  single 
track to double track, introducing high-speed rail, and building an urban mass rapid transit system.                 
 
5. 
Road  transport  subsector  development.  Recognizing  that  an  efficient  national 
connectivity is essential for further economic development and poverty reduction, the government 
has embarked on a national transport development plan since 2012. The plan aims to address 
key  binding  constraints  and  strengthen  efficiency  in  the  road  transport  subsector  through 
substantial  improvements  in  software  and  hardware. 2 The  key  achievements  of  the  plan  are 
capacity  strengthening  in  policy  planning,  programming  and  implementation  of  road  transport 
projects,  the  introduction  of  a  competitive  and  transparent  procurement  system,  and  the 
construction of about 5,000 km of a new highway network. Despite these positive developments 

                                                
1  Government  of  Thailand,  Ministry  of Transport,  Office  of  The  Permanent  Secretary.  2016.  Transport   Statistics.  
   Bangkok. 
2  Government of Thailand, National Economic and Social Development Board. 2011. The Eleventh National Economic 

and Social Development Plan, 2012–2016. Bangkok.  

 and  achievements,  Thailand’s  transport  sector  still  faces  key  challenges.  These  include  an 
inefficient national highway network and poor road safety. 
 
6. 
Inefficient national highway network. Much of the existing highway network is operating 
above  capacity,  resulting  in  congestion  and  inefficient  movement  of  goods  and  people.  The 
capacity of the existing roads is determined by highway widths and the number of lanes. About 
17% of the 70,660 km highway network in the country are four-lane highways, while the rest are 
two-lane highways.3 The road capacity of the highway network is limited by the two-lane highway 
configuration, leading to inefficient national connectivity for the movement of goods and people.4 
From 1995 to the present, the government has upgraded 4,197 km of national highways with high 
traffic  volumes  from  single  two-lane  to  divided  four-lane  highways.  Continued  investment  in 
upgrading national highways from two-lane to four-lane highways is required to ensure that the 
network has adequate road capacity for efficient transport to support economic development. 
 
7. 
Poor  road  safety.  The  country’s  road  safety  is  a  key  concern.  In  2015,  71,054  traffic 
accidents  and  6,432  deaths  from  those  accidents  were  recorded,  producing  a  fatality  rate  of 
9.6 per 100,000 people. 5 Though the number of deaths in traffic accidents have been declining 
since 2014, Thailand still has one of the  poorest road accident and fatality records among the 
members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations. 6 The poor road safety is attributed to 
inadequate safety features in road projects.               
 
8. 
Geographic disparities. Provinces in the northeastern region of Thailand are among the 
poorest in the country. 7 The average gross domestic product per capita of the northeastern region 
in  2015  was  $2,030,  which  is  only  slightly  greater  than  a  third  of  the  national  average  gross 
domestic product per capita of $5,890 in 2015.8 The GMS East–West Economic Corridor (EWEC), 
which  runs  from  Viet  Nam  through  the  Lao  PDR  and  Thailand  to  Myanmar,  linking  economic 
centers in the GMS, crosses northeastern Thailand. The development potential of the region is 
strong,  as  the  EWEC  could  serve  as  a  powerful  engine  for  regional  integration  and  inclusive 
economic  growth.9 However,  such  potential  has  not  been  fully  tapped  because  of  two  crucial 
factors  in  the  transport  sector:  an  inefficient  highway  network  resulting  from  inadequate  road 
capacity, and poor road safety. Investment in transport infrastructure in the northeastern region 
is  vital  to  help  unleash  development  potential  for  regional  integration  and  inclusive  economic 
growth.   
    
9. 
Strategic  context.  Strengthening  national  connectivity  in  poorer  provinces  to  enhance 
access  to  social  and  economic  opportunities  in  support  of  inclusive  growth  and  regional 
                                                
3  Government of Thailand, Ministry of Transport. 2015. Transport Infrastructure Development Plan. Bangkok. 
4  The standard design lane width for national highways is 3.5 meters per lane. The capacity of two-lane highways is 
2,000 vehicles  per  hour  while  that  of  divided  four-lane  highways  is  6,000  vehicles  per  hour.  Divided  four-lane 
highways have a central reservation to separate traffic traveling in opposite directions, resulting in higher speed and 
capacity, and improved safety by reducing the incidence of head-on collisions.  

5  Royal Thai Police. 2015. Traffic Accident Report. Bangkok. 
6  World Health Organization. 2015. Global Status Report on Road Safety, 2015. Geneva. 
7  The provinces are Khon Kaen, Udon Thani, Loei, Nong Khai, Mukdahan, Nakhon Phanom, Sakon Nakhon, Kalasin, 
Nakhon Ratchasima, Chaiyaphum, Yasothon, Ubon Ratchathani, Roi Et, Buriram, Surin, Maha Sarakham, Sisaket, 
Nong Bua Lamphu, Amnat Charoen, and Bueng Kan. 

8  Government of Thailand, Office of the National Economic and Social Development Board. 2016. National Economic 

and Social Statistics 2015. Bangkok. 

9  Along the GMS EWEC, the total trade value at the Mukdahan (Thailand)–Savannakhet (Lao PDR) border increased 
from 2010 ($97 million) to 2015 ($203 million), while at the Mae Sot (Thailand)– Myawaddy (Myanmar) border, trade 
increased by 73% from 2010 ($85 million) to 2015 ($148 million). Expansion of the EWEC catchment by improving 
the road network will help realize broader economic benefits and regional integration. 

2 

 

 

 integration  is  one  of  the  priority  policy  items  in  the  12th  National  Economic  and  Social 
Development  Plan,  2017–2021. 10  The  project  is  in  line  with  the  government’s  development 
strategy to improve national connectivity throughout the country. The country partnership strategy, 
2013–2016  for  Thailand  also  emphasizes  transport  infrastructure  development  to  improve 
domestic connectivity, which contributes to inclusive growth and regional integration.11 
 
10. 
Lessons. In 2009, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) provided a loan to Thailand for the 
GMS  Highway  Expansion  Project,  which  improved  national  highways  along  GMS  EWEC  and 
Southern Economic Corridor.12 Upon the successful completion of the GMS Highway Expansion 
Project  in  2016,  the  government  requested  ADB  to  provide  a  new  project  loan  to  finance  this 
phase 2 project.13 Key lessons are that giving attention to project readiness at planning stage, 
and  providing  up-front  support  to  the  executing  agency  on  procurement  will  facilitate  effective 
project implementation.  
 
11. 
The  proposed  project  will  improve  National  Highway  22  and  National  Highway  23  in 
northeast Thailand, which are key link roads near the EWEC. On National Highway 22, the annual 
average daily traffic is about 12,000. The annual average daily traffic on National Highway 23 is 
about  15,000.  To  address  such  large  traffic  volumes,  the  government  is  upgrading  National 
Highway 22 and National Highway 23 to divided four-lane highways. The proposed project will 
continue the government initiative by upgrading the remaining sections of National Highway 22 
and National Highway 23, which are currently single two-lane highways.  
 
B. 
 
The  project  is  aligned  with  the  following  impact:  access  to  social  and  economic 
12. 
opportunities enhanced (footnote 10). The project will have the following outcome: efficiency and 
safety of movements of goods and people on project roads improved.14 
 
C. 
 
13. 
Output 1: Sections of National Highway 22 and National Highway 23 upgraded. A 
total of about 125 km sections of National Highway 22 and National Highway 23 will be upgraded 
from single two-lane highways to divided four-lane highways. Road sections under the project for 
upgrading are from Nong Han to Phang Khon (about 37 km) and from Sakon Nakhon to Nakhon 
Phanom (about 33 km) of National Highway 22, and a section from Roi Et to Yasothon (about 55 
km) of National Highway 23.     
 
14. 
Output 2: Capacity in road safety management strengthened. To enhance the road 
safety features of the proposed upgrading of National Highway 22 and National Highway 23, the 
road  design  will  be  subjected  to  detailed  road  safety  audits  before  construction  commences, 
during  construction,  and  before  final  acceptance  of  the  completed  roads.  The  project  will  also 
strengthen  the  government’s  capacity  in  road  safety  management  through  safety  awareness 
training and hands-on experience in road safety audits. 

Impact and Outcome 

Outputs

13 ADB. 2017. Completion Report: Greater Mekong Subregion Highway Expansion Project. Manila. 
14 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 

3 

 

 4 

 

improving  procurement  efficiency.  This  will  continue 

 
15. 
Value added by ADB. ADB will add value to the project primarily by including international 
best practice in procurement and road safety. Throughout the project preparation, ADB shared 
expertise  on 
throughout  project 
implementation  to  promote  open  competition  and  support  the  government’s  procurement 
oversight and progress monitoring. Better road safety management, brought about by output 2, 
will improve the capacity of the executing agency in implementing other road projects. 
 
D. 
 
16. 
 
Detailed  cost  estimates  by  expenditure  category  and  by  financier  are  included  in  the 
17. 
project  administration manual  (PAM).15 The major  expenditure  items that constitute the  project 
are civil works and consulting services.  
 

The project is estimated to cost $213.6 million (Table 1).

Source: Asian Development Bank. 

 
18. 
The government has requested a regular loan of $99.4 million from ADB’s ordinary capital 
resources to help finance the project. The loan will have a 13-year term, including a grace period 
of 3 years; an annual interest rate determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered 
rate  (LIBOR)-based  lending  facility;  a  commitment  charge  of  0.15%  per  year;  and  such  other 
terms and conditions set forth in the draft loan agreement. Based on the straight-line method, the 
average maturity is 8.25 years, and there is no maturity premium payable to ADB.  
 
19. 
The summary financing plan is in Table 2. ADB will finance the expenditures in relation to 
civil  works and consulting services. The government will contribute $114.2 million to cover  the 
costs  of  civil  works,  consulting  services,  taxes  and  duties,  and  financing  charges  during 
implementation.

Implementation Arrangements 

 
E. 
 
The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 3 and described in detail in 
20. 
the  PAM.  The  level  of  project  readiness  is  high,  given  that  detailed  engineering  designs  have 
been  completed.  Preparation  for  the  recruitment  of  a  construction  supervision  consultant  and 
procurement of civil works has already started.

Source: Asian Development Bank. 

 
21. 
Special  financing  feature  to  meet  the  government’s  need.  ADB’s  UMICs  are 
sophisticated and heterogeneous, and each of them faces various development challenges. Use 
of  a  uniform  ADB  lending  approach  is  less  likely  to  meet  their  individual  development  needs. 
Some UMICs including Thailand are pressing ADB, to varying degrees, to be more responsive to 

5 

 

 their requirements and effective in delivering the desired outcomes. The government recognizes 
foreign  exchange  management  as  the  key  issue  for  borrowing  in  foreign  currency  to  finance 
infrastructure projects. Since the project expenses are expected to be largely paid in baht, while 
the ADB project loan proceeds are in United States (US) dollars, this creates a currency mismatch 
in project financing using ADB loan. The government is also exposed to foreign exchange and 
interest rate risks with liability in US dollars when taking an ADB London interbank offered rate-
based loan (LBL). 
 
The  government  adopts  an  established  two-step  strategy  to  address  the  currency 
22. 
mismatch  and  hedge  the  financial  risks  arising  from  foreign  borrowing.  First,  the  entire  loan 
proceeds from US dollars will be converted to baht to lock up the currency for project expenses. 
Second,  a cross  currency  interest  rate  swap  agreement  with  a  commercial  counterpart  will  be 
executed to manage the financial risk exposure resulting from the ADB loan. 
  
23. 
To help the government manage the foreign exchange and interest rate risks effectively, 
as a pilot project, this ADB loan will feature a single tranche disbursement arrangement. This will 
allow the full amount of ADB’s share of eligible expenditures for the project to be disbursed as an 
imprest advance after all contracts are awarded and signed. The government will convert the loan 
advance disbursed by ADB into baht to manage the financial risk exposures, and will keep the 
fund  in an  account to be established solely  for  the  project  purpose of  arranging the  payments 
directly to contractors and consultants for the project. The PDMO of the Ministry of Finance will 
be responsible for administering the fund and making payments to the contractors and consulting 
services  for  the  project.  The  PDMO  will  also  enter  into  a  cross-currency  interest  rate  swap 
agreement at the domestic swap market to hedge the financial risks for the repayment of the ADB 
LBL. The imprest fund procedure is described in detail in the PAM. 

 
24. 
The  introduction  of  this  customized  lending  structure  in  the  loan  will  be  important  to 
demonstrate ADB’s ability to remain a relevant and responsive development partner with UMICs. 
This customized lending structure will also facilitate a step towards a gradual shift to the use of 
the  country’s  financial  management  system  in  ADB  investment  lending  operations.  This  will 
improve country ownership, build capable institutions and effective systems necessary for better 
service delivery, and achieve sustainable development in the country. 

 
25. 
The  use  of  ADB’s  sovereign  local  currency  loan  product  for  this  project  has  been 
considered and discussed with the government. Given Thailand’s well-developed domestic debt 
market,  ADB’s  local  currency  loan  is  less  likely  to  be  favorable  in  terms  of  financial  costs 
compared with the government’s domestic borrowing. The government opts to take the ADB LBL 
in  US  dollars  with  the  abovementioned  customized  lending  structure.  The  introduction  of  this 
customized  lending  structure  in  an  ADB  LBL  project  loan  could  be  considered  an  innovative 
approach to support UMICs, in which the domestic debt markets are usually well developed. 

 

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

A. 

Technical 
 
26. 
The  project  is  technically  feasible.  It  incorporates  standard  design  requirements  and 
criteria of the DOH; and construction techniques used on all the government’s four-lane national 
highway projects in Thailand. All construction activities will be carried out within the existing right-
of-way (ROW). Engineering design documents and construction drawings are standard, and no 
technical issues are contemplated. 

6 

 

 Economic and Financial 

B. 
 
27. 
The project has an economic internal rate of return of 15.2% and a net present value of 
$152.7  million  at  a  discount  rate  of  9%. 16  The  key  measured  benefits  are  reduced  vehicle 
operating  costs,  reduced  travel  time,  and  reduced  risk  of  fatal  and  nonfatal  injury  from  road 
accidents,  compared  with  the  without-project  case.  Connecting  to  the  Thai  border  facility  of 
Nakhon Phanom, the upgraded project road will offer a more efficient link between producers in 
Thailand  and  consumer  markets  in  neighboring  GMS  countries,  and  strengthen  a  land  bridge 
option  for  accessing  ocean  shipping  routes  from  the  GMS,  enhancing  regional  economic 
integration.  
 
28. 
The executing agency and project owner, DOH, is a general government sector unit, and 
the project is nonrevenue generating and non-cost recovery. Hence, the financial analysis focuses 
on the financial sustainability of the project. The financial analysis assesses the project executing 
agency’s  financial  capacity  to  meet  the  recurrent  costs  of  operating  and  maintaining  the 
developed facilities in a sustainable manner. The financial management assessment undertaken 
during  project  preparation  assessed  the  DOH’s  financial  capacity  to  maintain  the  project 
sustainably. The analysis concluded that the DOH has sufficient financial management capacity, 
within  the  government’s  budgetary  procedures,  for  the  recurrent  expenditures  required  for 
maintaining and operating the project in a sustainable manner. The DOH has identified the annual 
incremental recurrent costs of the project and has requested annual budget funding for covering 
them. Given the government’s strong commitment to the four-lane expansion program for national 
highways,  adequate  budgetary  allocation  for  covering  the  recurrent  costs  of  operating  and 
maintaining  the  project  is  reasonably  expected.  The  project  team  will  incorporate  specific 
assurance  regarding  the  government  provision  of  budgetary  resources  and  experienced  and 
qualified  staff  for  project  sustainability  in  the  loan  documentation.  The  project  is  therefore 
considered financially sustainable.  
 
C. 
 
29. 
The project team undertook a project procurement risk assessment to assess the DOH’s 
capacity  with  regard  to  organization  and  staffing,  information  management,  procurement 
practices,  and  accountability  measures.  The  DOH  is  adequately  staffed  and  functional  for 
procurement  activities;  and  has  good  experience  in  the  procurement  of  works  and  consulting 
services  under  externally  assisted  projects  funded  by  ADB,  the  World  Bank,  and  the  Japan 
International Cooperation Agency. Procurement of civil works and recruitment of consultants to 
be financed by the loan follow ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2015, as amended from time to 
time) and Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). All contract 
packages are subject to prior review by ADB. The risk rating for procurement is moderate.  
 
The  financial  management  assessment  confirms  that  the  DOH  has  adequate  financial 
30. 
management  capacity  and  arrangements  for  implementing  the  project.  The  DOH  has  a  good 
understanding of  ADB’s financial management  policies and procedures, having  undertaken  an 
ADB-financed project in the past. The financial management assessment also  reveals that the 
PDMO  has  adequate  capacity  to  administer  the  ADB  loan  proceeds,  examine  withdrawal 
applications, and arrange payments to contractors and services. This is the first time the PDMO 
will handle loan disbursements from ADB directly. ADB, through the Thailand Resident Mission, 
will  provide  direct  support  to  the  PDMO  during  project  implementation  to  ensure  efficient 
disbursement.  ADB  will  conduct  a  workshop  for  the  PDMO  and  DOH  to  help  deepen  their 

Governance 

                                                
16 Economic and Financial Analysis (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 

7 

 

 8 

 

understanding  of  ADB’s  loan  disbursement  process.  The  PAM  provides  the  disbursement 
arrangements in detail. 
 
31. 
The project team identified and assessed ADB’s fiduciary risks. To ensure ADB’s financial 
control and continued oversight of the project resulting from the single tranche disbursement, ADB 
devised and incorporated specific covenants and measures in the loan documents. Overall, the 
financial management risk is rated moderate.     

 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
32. 
with  the  government,  including  the  DOH  and  PDMO.  The  specific  policy  requirements  and 
supplementary measures are described in the PAM. 

D. 

 
Poverty, Social, and Gender 
 
The  project  is  categorized  as  having  no  gender  elements.  Nevertheless,  gender  and 
33. 
development activities are integrated and mainstreamed throughout the resettlement plan. The 
DOH will ensure that the principles of gender equality aimed at increasing project benefits and 
impacts on women in the project area are followed during the implementation of the plan. These 
principles  include  (i)  equal  chance  for  women  in  getting  hired  for  unskilled  work  and  equal 
remuneration for the same work as men; (ii) inviting women to be represented in consultations 
during  implementation  of  the  plan,  and  both  women  and  men  participating  in  the  discussions; 
(iii) prioritizing women in accessing income restoration programs, which will be provided during 
the  implementation  of  the  plan;  and  (iv)  developing  disaggregated  monitoring  indicators  for 
monitoring social benefits, economic opportunities, livelihood, and resettlement activities. 
 
34. 
To meet the challenge of an increase in sexually transmitted infections and HIV/AIDS that 
can be directly linked to construction-based activities, the project team included several mitigation 
measures in the summary poverty reduction and social strategy.17 As part of an HIV awareness 
campaign, activities will include providing advice on access to testing and treatment for HIV and 
other sexually transmitted infections, and increasing awareness of behavior that increases risks. 
Awareness  activities  will  also  address  human  trafficking,  including  capacity  building  of  the 
executing  agency,  awareness  on  safe  migration,  and  community  monitoring.  The  project  will 
support measures to reinforce the negative impacts of people trafficking in local communities. 
 
E. 

Safeguards 
 
In  compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009),  the  project’s  safeguard 

35. 
categories are in paras. 36–40.18 
 
36. 
Environment (category  B). The  project  is  not  anticipated to cause  significant  adverse 
environmental impacts as road expansion activities will be confined within the ROW of the project 
with  only  minor  and  short-term  environmental  impacts  during  construction.  The  project  road 
sections  in  National  Highway  22  and  National  Highway  23  are  not  within  any  ecologically 
protected  area.  The  DOH  prepared  an  initial  environmental  examination  (IEE)  to  meet  the 
requirements  of  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  and  this  includes  an  environmental 
management plan (EMP). The recommended environmental mitigation measures and monitoring 
activities set out in the EMP cover the preconstruction, construction, and operation stages of the 
project. The DOH has a unit for resettlement and environmental protection that is well-staffed with 

                                                
17 Summary of Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy (accessible from the list of lined documents in Appendix 2). 
18  ADB. Safeguard Categories. https://www.adb.org/site/safeguards/safeguard-categories. 

 specialists  in  environmental  protection  and  has  experience  in  ADB  projects.  The  construction 
supervision consultant’s environmental specialists will assist DOH during project implementation. 
The  EMP,  which  also  defines  the  institutional  arrangements  and  responsibilities  for  the 
implementation of the plan, will be included in the bidding documents and ensuing contracts. The 
contractors  will  be  required  to  prepare  site-specific  contractor’s  EMP  before  commencing 
construction.  
 
37. 
The DOH conducted public consultations to inform the stakeholders about the project and 
know  their  concerns so  that  these  may  be  adequately  addressed.  The  highlights  of  the  public 
consultations  are 
IEE,  with  additional  consultations  scheduled  during  project 
implementation. The DOH developed a grievance redress mechanism for resolving environmental 
complaints for the project. The DOH will prepare an updated IEE should there be major changes 
to  the  project  design,  which  will  include  additional  mitigation  measures  to  the  EMP  and/or 
contractor’s EMP to address unanticipated environmental impacts that were not identified in the 
original IEE. The IEE and updated IEE, if any, will be disclosed on ADB’s website. 

the 

in 

 
Involuntary  resettlement  (category  B).  The  project  will  not  entail  any  further  land 
38. 
acquisition, as the land acquisition for the ROW of the project has been completed since 1967. 
The involuntary resettlement safeguard is mainly to mitigate and address minor impacts that will 
occur  within  the  ROW.  The  detailed  inventory  prepared  during  project  preparation  identified 
155 households that could be affected by the project, of which 11 will be severely affected. All 
these  households  are  using  government  land  unlawfully  within  the  ROW,  and  all  impacts  are 
characterized as economic displacements of shop owners and paddy farmers.  

 
 The  project  team  prepared  a  resettlement  plan  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard 
39. 
Policy  Statement.  The  plan  will  ensure  measures  for  affected  persons  to  assist  them  in 
maintaining if not improving on their socioeconomic pre-project conditions. Measures in the plan 
include (i) the gradual transfer of shops by the DOH and contractors on the residual area along 
the  road;  (ii)  farmers  encroaching  and  tilling  the  land  within  the  ROW  will  have  to  discontinue 
farming activities; and (iii) linking affected households with livelihood assistance programs. The 
project team carried out consultations with affected households during the preparation of the plan 
and the households acknowledged willingness to terminate and transfer their income-generating 
activities when the project commences. The plan was disclosed on ADB’s website on 14 June 
2017.  A  grievance  mechanism  and  monitoring  system  have  been  established  per  Thai  legal 
framework.  With  the  assistance  of  a  resettlement  specialist,  DOH  will  be  responsible  for 
implementing the plan.  
 
40. 
project roads do not cross or affect any communities of indigenous peoples. 
 
F. 
 
41. 
Significant  risks  and  mitigating  measures  are  summarized  in  Table  4  and  described  in 
detail in the risk assessment and risk management plan.19 The risks are assessed as manageable 
by adopting the mitigating measures. 
 

Indigenous peoples (category C). No indigenous peoples are present in the area as the

IV. 

ASSURANCES 

42. 
The government and the DOH have assured ADB that implementation of the project shall 
conform  to  all  applicable  ADB  policies,  including  those  concerning  anticorruption  measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the PAM and loan documents. 
 
43. 
which are set forth in the draft loan agreement. 
 

The government and the DOH have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, 

V. 

RECOMMENDATION 

44. 
I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loan of $99,400,000 
to  the  Kingdom  of  Thailand  for  the  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  Highway  Expansion  Phase  2 
Project, from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, in regular terms, with interest to be determined in 
accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; for a term 
of  13  years,  including  a  grace  period  of  3  years;  and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  as  are 
substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan agreement presented to the Board. 
 
 
 

Takehiko Nakao 
President 

28 September 2017
